DOC.HEAD: China Picks Own Turmoil as Top News Event of Year
DOC.TEXT: China's repression of pro-democracy protests was the top world news event of 1989, an official newspaper said today. The pro-democray revolution in Eastern Europe came in second, according to a list of the top 10 stories published in the China Daily. The newspaper said the crushing of the student-led Chinese rebellion in June, the election of Jiang Zemin as the new Communist Party chief and China's renewed commitment to socialism were the most significant events of the year. Rounding out the top 10 stories were: 3. The end of colonial rule in Namibia. 4. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's May visit to China that normalized relations between the two countries. 5. The U.S. invasion of Panama, ``arousing worldwide condemnation.'' 6. War in Lebanon and the assassination of newly elected President Rene Mouawad. 7. The Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan. 8. Strong earthquakes in San Francisco and northern China. 9. Scandals forcing two Japanese prime ministers to resign. 10. Global concern over the greenhouse effect and other environmental problems.
